prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. A television's price was discounted $40\%$ and then slashed another $40\%$ during a liquidation sale. By what percent has the original price been reduced?
solution: Let the original price of the television be $T$. Then the price is now $0.6(0.6T)=0.36T$. Thus overall the price has been reduced by $1-0.36=\boxed{64\%}$.
gpt_response:
Okay, so let's pretend we have a yummy cookie that we want to sell on the playground. We decide to give a big discount of $40\%$ off the original price. Then, we decide to give another $40\%$ off during a big sale.

When we give the first $40\%$ discount, that means we only charge $60\%$ of the original price. Then, when we give the second $40\%$ discount, we only charge $60\%$ of the remaining $60\%$.

To figure out how much we are charging after both discounts, we can multiply $60\%$ by $60\%$ to get $36\%$. So, the original price has been reduced by $100\% - 36\% = 64\%$. Wow, that's a big discount!
solution_prompt:

When we give the first $40\%$ discount, that means we only charge $60\%$ of the original price. Then, when we give the second $40\%$ discount, we only charge $60\%$ of the remaining $60\%$.

To figure out how much we are charging after both discounts, we can multiply $60\%$ by $60\%$ to get $36\%$. So, the original price has been reduced by $100\% - 36\% = 64\%$. Wow, that's a big discount!
